Provably Doubly Accelerated Federated Learning:
The First Theoretically Successful Combination of
Local Training and Communication Compression

Laurent Condat11{\!\>}^{1}   Ivan Agarský2,323{\!\>}^{2,3}   Peter Richtárik11{\!\>}^{1}
xx
1King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST)
Thuwal, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia
2Brno University of Technology
Brno, Czech Republic
3Kempelen Institute of Intelligent Technologies (KInIT)
Bratislava, Slovakia
(January 2023)
Abstract

In federated learning, a large number of users are involved in a global learning task, in a collaborative way. They alternate local computations and two-way communication with a distant orchestrating server. Communication, which can be slow and costly, is the main bottleneck in this setting. To reduce the communication load and therefore accelerate distributed gradient descent, two strategies are popular: 1) communicate less frequently; that is, perform several iterations of local computations between the communication rounds; and 2) communicate compressed information instead of full-dimensional vectors. We propose the first algorithm for distributed optimization and federated learning, which harnesses these two strategies jointly and converges linearly to an exact solution in the strongly convex setting, with a doubly accelerated rate: our algorithm benefits from the two acceleration mechanisms provided by local training and compression, namely a better dependency on the condition number of the functions and on the dimension of the model, respectively.

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) is a novel paradigm for training supervised machine learning models. Initiated a few years ago in several foundational papers (Konečný et al., 2016a, ; Konečný et al., 2016b, ; McMahan et al.,, 2017; Bonawitz et al.,, 2017), it has become a rapidly growing interdisciplinary field. The key idea is to exploit the wealth of information stored on edge devices, such as mobile phones, sensors and hospital workstations, to train global models, in a collaborative way, while handling a multitude of challenges, like data privacy concerns (Kairouz et al.,, 2021; Li et al.,, 2020; Wang et al.,, 2021). In contrast to centralized learning in a datacenter, in FL, the parallel computing units have private data stored on each of them and communicate with a distant orchestrating server, which aggregates the information and synchronizes the computations, so that the process reaches a consensus and converges to a globally optimal model. In this framework, communication between the parallel workers and the server, which can take place over the internet or cell phone network, can be slow, costly, and unreliable. Thus, communication dominates the overall time cost of the process and is the main bottleneck to be addressed by the community, before FL can be widely adopted and applied in our daily lives.

The baseline algorithm of distributed Gradient Descent (GD) alternates between two steps: one round of parallel computation of the local function gradients at the current model estimate, and one round of communication of these gradient vectors to the server, which averages them to form the new estimate for the next iteration. To decrease the communication load, two strategies can be used: 1) communicate less frequently, or equivalently do more local computations between successive communication rounds; or 2) compress the communicated vectors. We detail these two strategies in Section 1.3. In this paper, we combine them, within a unified framework for randomized communication, and derive a new algorithm named CompressedScaffnew, with local training and communication compression. It is variance-reduced (Hanzely and Richtárik,, 2019; Gorbunov et al., 2020a, ; Gower et al.,, 2020), so that it converges to an exact solution, and provably benefits from the two mechanisms: the convergence rate is doubly accelerated, with a better dependency on the condition number of the functions and on the dimension of the model, in comparison with GD. In the remainder of this section, we formulate the convex optimization problem to solve, we propose a new model to characterize the communication complexity, and we present the state of the art.

1.1 Formalism

We consider a distributed client-server setting, in which n≥2𝑛2n\geq 2 clients, or compute nodes, perform computations in parallel and communicate back and forth with a server, or master node. We study the convex optimization problem:

minimizex∈ℝdf​(x)≔1n​∑i=1nfi​(x),≔subscriptminimize𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑𝑓𝑥1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥\operatorname*{minimize}_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\ f(x)\coloneqq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(x), (1)

where each function fi:ℝd→ℝ:subscript𝑓𝑖→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf_{i}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} models the individual cost and underlying private data of client i∈[n]≔{1,…,n}𝑖delimited-[]𝑛≔1…𝑛i\in[n]\coloneqq\{1,\ldots,n\}. The number n𝑛n of clients, as well as the dimension d≥1𝑑1d\geq 1 of the model, are typically large. This problem is of key importance as it is an abstraction of empirical risk minimization, the dominant framework in supervised machine learning.

For every i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], the function fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is supposed L𝐿L-smooth and μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex111A function f:ℝd→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is said to be L𝐿L-smooth if it is differentiable and its gradient is Lipschitz continuous with constant L𝐿L; that is, for every x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and y∈ℝd𝑦superscriptℝ𝑑y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, ‖∇f​(x)−∇f​(y)‖≤L​‖x−y‖norm∇𝑓𝑥∇𝑓𝑦𝐿norm𝑥𝑦\|\nabla f(x)-\nabla f(y)\|\leq L\|x-y\|, where, here and throughout the paper, the norm is the Euclidean norm. f𝑓f is said to be μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex if f−μ2∥⋅∥2f-\frac{\mu}{2}\|\cdot\|^{2} is convex. We refer to Bauschke and Combettes, (2017) for such standard notions of convex analysis., for some L≥μ>0𝐿𝜇0L\geq\mu>0 (except in Section 3.2 where we study the merely convex case, i.e. μ=0𝜇0\mu=0). Thus, the sought solution x⋆superscript𝑥⋆x^{\star} of (1) exists and is unique. We define κ≔Lμ≔𝜅𝐿𝜇\kappa\coloneqq\frac{L}{\mu}.

To solve the problem (1), the baseline algorithm of Gradient Descent (GD) consists in the simple iteration, for t=0,1,…,𝑡01…t=0,1,\ldots,

xt+1≔xt−γn​∑i=1n∇fi​(xt),≔superscript𝑥𝑡1superscript𝑥𝑡𝛾𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝑥𝑡x^{t+1}\coloneqq x^{t}-\frac{\gamma}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\nabla f_{i}(x^{t}),

for some stepsize γ∈(0,2L)𝛾02𝐿\gamma\in(0,\frac{2}{L}). That is, at iteration t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0, xtsuperscript𝑥𝑡x^{t} is first broadcast by the server to all clients, which compute the gradients ∇fi​(xt)∈ℝd∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝑥𝑡superscriptℝ𝑑\nabla f_{i}(x^{t})\in\mathbb{R}^{d} in parallel. These vectors are then sent by the clients to the server, which averages them and performs the gradient descent step. It is well known that for γ=Θ​(1L)𝛾Θ1𝐿\gamma=\Theta(\frac{1}{L}), GD converges linearly, with iteration complexity 𝒪​(κ​log⁡(ϵ−1))𝒪𝜅superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mathcal{O}\big{(}\kappa\log(\epsilon^{-1})\big{)} to reach ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-accuracy. Since d𝑑d-dimensional vectors are communicated at every iteration, the communication complexity of GD in number of reals is 𝒪​(d​κ​log⁡(ϵ−1))𝒪𝑑𝜅superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mathcal{O}\big{(}d\kappa\log(\epsilon^{-1})\big{)}. Our goal is a twofold acceleration of GD, with a better dependency to both κ𝜅\kappa and d𝑑d in this communication complexity. We want to achieve this goal by leveraging the best of the two popular mechanisms of local training and communication compression.

1.2 Asymmetric communication regime

Uplink and downlink communication. We call uplink communication (UpCom) the parallel transmission of data from the clients to the server and downlink communication (DownCom) the broadcast of the same message from the server to all clients. UpCom is usually significantly slower than DownCom, just like uploading is slower than downloading on the internet or cell phone network. This can be due to the asymmetry of the service provider’s systems or protocols used on the communication network, or cache memory and aggregation speed constraints of the server, which has to decode and average the large number n𝑛n of vectors received at the same time during UpCom.

Communication complexity. We measure the UpCom or DownCom complexity as the expected number of communication rounds needed to estimate a solution with ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-accuracy, multiplied by the number of real values sent during a communication round between the server and any client. Thus, the UpCom or DownCom complexity of GD is 𝒪​(d​κ​log⁡(ϵ−1))𝒪𝑑𝜅superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mathcal{O}\big{(}d\kappa\log(\epsilon^{-1})\big{)}. We leave if for future work to refine this model of counting real numbers, to take into account how sequences of real numbers are quantized into bitstreams, achieving further compression (Horváth et al.,, 2022; Albasyoni et al.,, 2020).

A model for the overall communication complexity. Since UpCom is usually slower than DownCom, we propose to measure the total communication (TotalCom) complexity as a weighted sum of the two UpCom and DownCom complexities: we assume that the UpCom cost is 1 (unit of time per transmitted real number), whereas the downCom cost is c∈[0,1]𝑐01c\in[0,1]. Therefore,

TotalCom=UpCom+c.DownCom.formulae-sequenceTotalComUpCom𝑐DownCom\mbox{TotalCom}=\mbox{UpCom}+c.\mbox{DownCom}. (2)

A symmetric but unrealistic communication regime corresponds to c=1𝑐1c=1, whereas ignoring downCom and focusing on UpCom, which is usually the limiting factor, corresponds to c=0𝑐0c=0. We will provide explicit expressions of the parameters of our algorithm to minimize the TotalCom complexity for any given c∈[0,1]𝑐01c\in[0,1], keeping in mind that realistic settings correspond to small values of c𝑐c. Thus, our model of communication complexity is richer than only considering c=0𝑐0c=0, as is usually the case.

1.3 Communication efficiency in FL: state of the art

Two approaches come naturally to mind to decrease the communication load: Local Training (LT), which consists in communicating less frequently than at every iteration, and Communication Compression (CC), which consists in sending less than d𝑑d floats during every communication round. In this section, we review existing work related to these two strategies.

1.3.1 Local Training (LT)

LT is a conceptually simple and surprisingly powerful communication-acceleration technique. It consists in the clients performing multiple local GD steps instead of only one, between successive communication rounds. This intuitively results in “better” information being communicated, so that less communication rounds are needed to achieve a given accuracy. As shown by ample empirical evidence, LT is very efficient in practice. It was popularized by the FedAvg algorithm of McMahan et al., (2017), in which LT is a core component, along with other features such as data sampling and partial participation. However, LT was heuristic and no theory was provided in their paper. LT was analyzed in several works, in the homogeneous, or i.i.d. data, regime (Haddadpour and Mahdavi,, 2019), and in the heterogeneous regime, which is more representative in FL (Khaled et al.,, 2019, 2020; Stich,, 2019; Woodworth et al.,, 2020; Gorbunov et al.,, 2021; Glasgow et al.,, 2022). It stands out that LT suffers from so-called client drift, which is the fact that the local model obtained by client i𝑖i after several local GD steps approaches the minimizer of its local cost function fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}. The discrepancy between the exact solution x⋆superscript𝑥⋆x^{\star} of (1) and the approximate solution obtained at convergence of LT was characterized in Malinovsky et al., (2020). This deficiency of LT was corrected in the Scaffold algorithm of Karimireddy et al., (2020) by introducing control variates, which correct for the client drift, so that the algorithm converges linearly to the exact solution. S-Local-GD (Gorbunov et al.,, 2021) and FedLin (Mitra et al.,, 2021) were later proposed, with similar convergence properties. Yet, despite the empirical superiority of these recent algorithms relying on LT, their communication complexity remains the same as vanilla GD, i.e. 𝒪​(d​κ​log⁡(ϵ−1))𝒪𝑑𝜅superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mathcal{O}\big{(}d\kappa\log(\epsilon^{-1})\big{)}.

It is only very recently that Scaffnew was proposed by Mishchenko et al., (2022), a LT algorithm finally achieving proved accelerated communication complexity, with a 𝒪​(d​κ​log⁡(ϵ−1))𝒪𝑑𝜅superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mathcal{O}\big{(}d\sqrt{\kappa}\log(\epsilon^{-1})\big{)} rate for both UpCom and DownCom. In Scaffnew, communication is triggered randomly with a small probability p𝑝p at every iteration. Thus, the expected number of local GD steps between two communication rounds is 1/p1𝑝1/p. By choosing p=Θ​(1/κ)𝑝Θ1𝜅p=\Theta(1/\sqrt{\kappa}), the optimal dependency on κ𝜅\sqrt{\kappa} instead of κ𝜅\kappa is obtained. Thus, the discovery of Scaffnew is an important milestone, as it provides the first theoretical confirmation that LT is a communication acceleration mechanism. In this paper, we propose to go even further and tackle the multiplicative factor d𝑑d in the complexity of Scaffnew.

1.3.2 Communication Compression (CC)

To decrease the communication complexity, a widely used strategy is to make use of (lossy) compression; that is, a possibly randomized mapping 𝒞:ℝd→ℝd:𝒞→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{C}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{d} is applied to the vector x𝑥x that needs to be communicated, with the property that it is much faster to transfer 𝒞​(x)𝒞𝑥\mathcal{C}(x) than the full d𝑑d-dimensional vector x𝑥x. A popular sparsifying compressor is rand-k𝑘k, for some k∈[d]≔{1,…,d}𝑘delimited-[]𝑑≔1…𝑑k\in[d]\coloneqq\{1,\ldots,d\}, which multiplies k𝑘k elements of x𝑥x, chosen uniformly at random, by d/k𝑑𝑘d/k, and sets the other ones to zero. If the receiver knows which coordinates have been selected, e.g. by running the same pseudo-random generator, only these k𝑘k elements of x𝑥x are actually communicated, so that the communication complexity is divided by the compression factor d/k𝑑𝑘d/k. Another sparsifying compressor is top-k𝑘k, which keeps the k𝑘k elements of x𝑥x with largest absolute values unchanged and sets the other ones to zero. Besides sparsifying compressors (Alistarh et al.,, 2018; Wangni et al.,, 2018; Xu et al.,, 2021), quantization techniques are also widely used, and consist in representing the real elements of x𝑥x using fewer bits (Alistarh et al.,, 2017; Wen et al.,, 2017; Albasyoni et al.,, 2020; Dutta et al.,, 2020; Xu et al.,, 2021; Horváth et al.,, 2022). Some compressors, like rand-k𝑘k, are unbiased; that is, 𝔼​[𝒞​(x)]=x𝔼delimited-[]𝒞𝑥𝑥\mathbb{E}\!\left[\mathcal{C}(x)\right]=x for every x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, where 𝔼​[⋅]𝔼delimited-[]⋅\mathbb{E}[\cdot] denotes the expectation. On the other hand, compressors like top-k𝑘k are biased (Beznosikov et al.,, 2020).

The variance-reduced algorithm DIANA (Mishchenko et al.,, 2019), later extended in several ways (Horváth et al.,, 2022; Gorbunov et al., 2020a, ; Condat and Richtárik,, 2022), is a major contribution to the field, as it converges linearly with a large class of unbiased compressors. For instance, when the clients use independent rand-111 compressors for UpCom, the UpCom complexity of DIANA is 𝒪​((κ​(1+dn)+d)​log⁡(ϵ−1))𝒪𝜅1𝑑𝑛𝑑superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mathcal{O}\big{(}(\kappa(1+\frac{d}{n})+d)\log(\epsilon^{-1})\big{)}. If n𝑛n is large, this is much better than with GD. Algorithms converging linearly with biased compressors have been proposed recently, like EF21 (Richtárik et al.,, 2021; Fatkhullin et al.,, 2021; Condat et al.,, 2022), but the theory is less mature and the acceleration potential not as clear as with unbiased compressors. Our algorithm CompressedScaffnew benefits from CC with specific unbiased compressors, with even more acceleration than DIANA. Also, the focus in DIANA is on UpCom and its DownCom step is the same as in GD, with the full model broadcast at every iteration, so that its TotalCom complexity can be worse than the one of GD. Extensions of DIANA with bidirectional CC, i.e. compression in both UpCom and DownCom, have been proposed (Gorbunov et al., 2020b, ; Philippenko and Dieuleveut,, 2020; Liu et al.,, 2020; Condat and Richtárik,, 2022), but this does not improve its TotalCom complexity; see also Philippenko and Dieuleveut, (2021) and references therein on bidirectional CC.

2 Goals, challenges, contributions

Now that a breakthrough in the communication barrier of FL has been made with Scaffnew, which reduced κ𝜅\kappa to κ𝜅\sqrt{\kappa} in the communication complexity, with a simple LT method and without additional assumptions (e.g., data similarity or stronger smoothness assumptions), our goal is to achieve communication efficiency by further reducing the dependency on the dimension d𝑑d, by means of CC. We achieve this goal with our proposed algorithm CompressedScaffnew: as proved in Theorem 4.1, if c𝑐c is small enough, its TotalCom complexity is

𝒪​((d​κn+d​κ+d)​log⁡(ϵ−1)).𝒪𝑑𝜅𝑛𝑑𝜅𝑑superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mathcal{O}\!\left(\left(d\frac{\sqrt{\kappa}}{\sqrt{n}}+\sqrt{d}\sqrt{\kappa}+d\right)\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\right)\!.

This double acceleration is all the more remarkable, given that it is very challenging to combine LT and CC. In the strongly convex and heterogeneous case considered here, the methods Qsparse-local-SGD (Basu et al.,, 2020) and FedPAQ (Reisizadeh et al.,, 2020) do not converge linearly. The only linearly converging LT + CC algorithm we are aware of is FedCOMGATE (Haddadpour et al.,, 2021). But its rate is 𝒪​(d​κ​log⁡(ϵ−1))𝒪𝑑𝜅superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mathcal{O}\big{(}d\kappa\log(\epsilon^{-1})\big{)}, which does not show any acceleration. By contrast, our algorithm is the first, to the best of our knowledge, to exhibit a doubly-accelerated linear rate, by leveraging LT and CC. Random reshuffling, which can be seen as a kind of LT, has been combined with CC in Sadiev et al., (2022). The TotalCom complexity of the various algorithms is reported in Table 1.

We build upon the analysis of Scaffnew to design our new algorithm. In short,

𝖢𝗈𝗆𝗉𝗋𝖾𝗌𝗌𝖾𝖽𝖲𝖼𝖺𝖿𝖿𝗇𝖾𝗐=𝖦𝖣+LT⏟𝖲𝖼𝖺𝖿𝖿𝗇𝖾𝗐+CC.𝖢𝗈𝗆𝗉𝗋𝖾𝗌𝗌𝖾𝖽𝖲𝖼𝖺𝖿𝖿𝗇𝖾𝗐subscript⏟𝖦𝖣LT𝖲𝖼𝖺𝖿𝖿𝗇𝖾𝗐CC{\sf\color[rgb]{0.8,0.0,0.0}{CompressedScaffnew}}=\underbrace{{\sf\color[rgb]{0.8,0.0,0.0}{GD}}+\mbox{LT}}_{{\sf\color[rgb]{0.8,0.0,0.0}{Scaffnew}}}{}+\mbox{CC}.

This program of combining LT and CC looks simple at first glance, and it seems we just have to ‘plug’ compressors into Scaffnew. But this is far from being the case! First, we had to redesign the mechanism behind Scaffnew, which is not ProxSkip (Mishchenko et al.,, 2022) any more, but a new algorithm (Algorithm 2 in the Appendix) with two, instead of one, randomization mechanisms for managing the model estimates and the control variates. Both mechanisms combine probabilistic communication and compression with a random mask, but in different ways. If there is no compression, the two mechanisms coincide, since there is only one source of randomness, which is the coin flip to trigger communication, and CompressedScaffnew reverts to Scaffnew, hence its name. Second, our approach relies on a dedicated design of the compressors, so that the messages sent by the different clients complement each other, to keep a tight control of the variance after aggregation.

We want to stress that our goal is to deepen our theoretical understanding and to reveal the potential of the two LT and CC mechanisms, which are intuitive, effective, and widely used in practice. Thus, GD is at the core of our approach, and CompressedScaffnew reverts to GD if there is no compression and p𝑝p, the probability of communication, is one. There are certainly other ways to design communication-efficient algorithms, and Nesterov acceleration comes to our mind (Nesterov,, 2004): replacing GD by accelerated GD also yields κ𝜅\sqrt{\kappa} instead of κ𝜅\kappa in the complexity. Pursuing this path is somehow orthogonal to our approach, which, again, is to combine and get the best of LT and CC, not to get the best possible complexity per se.

3 Proposed algorithm CompressedScaffnew

The proposed algorithm CompressedScaffnew is shown as Algorithm 1. At every iteration t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0, every client i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n] performs a gradient descent step with respect to its private cost fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}, evaluated at its local model xitsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{i}^{t}, with a correction term by its control variate hitsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑡h_{i}^{t}. This yields a prediction x^itsuperscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑖𝑡\hat{x}_{i}^{t} of the updated local model. Then a random coin flip is made, to decide whether communication occurs or not. Communication occurs with probability p∈(0,1]𝑝01p\in(0,1], with p𝑝p typically small. If there is no communication, xit+1superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡1x_{i}^{t+1} is simply set as x^itsuperscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑖𝑡\hat{x}_{i}^{t} and hisubscriptℎ𝑖h_{i} is unchanged. If communication occurs, every client sends a compressed version of x^itsuperscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑖𝑡\hat{x}_{i}^{t}; that is, it sends only a few of its elements, selected randomly according to the rule explained in Figure 1 and known by both the clients and the server (for decoding). The server aggregates the received vectors and forms x¯tsuperscript¯𝑥𝑡\bar{x}^{t}, which is broadcast to all clients. They all resume with this fresh estimate of the solution. Every client updates its control variates hisubscriptℎ𝑖h_{i} by modifying only the coordinates which have been involved in the communication process; that is, for which qitsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖𝑡q_{i}^{t} has a one. Indeed, the other coordinates of x^itsuperscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑖𝑡\hat{x}_{i}^{t} have not participated to the formation of x¯tsuperscript¯𝑥𝑡\bar{x}^{t}, so the received vector x¯tsuperscript¯𝑥𝑡\bar{x}^{t} does not contain information relevant to update hitsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑡h_{i}^{t} at these coordinates.

The probability p∈(0,1]𝑝01p\in(0,1] of communication controls the amount of LT, since the expected number of local GD steps between two successive communication rounds is 1/p1𝑝1/p. If p=1𝑝1p=1, communication happens at every iteration and LT is disabled. The sparsity index s∈{2,…,n}𝑠2…𝑛s\in\{2,\ldots,n\} controls the amount of compression: the lower s𝑠s, the more compression. If s=n𝑠𝑛s=n and η=1𝜂1\eta=1, there is no compression and 𝒞it​(v)=vsubscriptsuperscript𝒞𝑡𝑖𝑣𝑣\mathcal{C}^{t}_{i}(v)=v for any v𝑣v; then CompressedScaffnew reverts to Scaffnew.

Our main result, stating linear convergence of CompressedScaffnew to the exact solution x⋆superscript𝑥⋆x^{\star} of (1), is the following:

Theorem 3.1.

In CompressedScaffnew, suppose that

0<γ<2Land0<η≤n​(s−1)s​(n−1)∈(12,1].formulae-sequence0𝛾2𝐿and0𝜂𝑛𝑠1𝑠𝑛11210<\gamma<\frac{2}{L}\quad\mbox{and}\quad 0<\eta\leq\frac{n(s-1)}{s(n-1)}\in\left(\frac{1}{2},1\right]. (3)

For every t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0, define the Lyapunov function

Ψt≔1γ​∑i=1n‖xit−x⋆‖2+γp2​η​n−1s−1​∑i=1n‖hit−hi⋆‖2,≔superscriptΨ𝑡1𝛾superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡superscript𝑥⋆2𝛾superscript𝑝2𝜂𝑛1𝑠1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖⋆2\Psi^{t}\coloneqq\frac{1}{\gamma}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|x_{i}^{t}-x^{\star}\right\|^{2}+\frac{\gamma}{p^{2}\eta}\frac{n-1}{s-1}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|h_{i}^{t}-h_{i}^{\star}\right\|^{2}, (4)

where x⋆superscript𝑥⋆x^{\star} is the unique solution to (1) and hi⋆=∇fi​(x⋆)superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖⋆∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝑥⋆h_{i}^{\star}=\nabla f_{i}(x^{\star}). Then CompressedScaffnew converges linearly: for every t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0,

𝔼​[Ψt]≤ρt​Ψ0,𝔼delimited-[]superscriptΨ𝑡superscript𝜌𝑡superscriptΨ0\mathbb{E}\!\left[\Psi^{t}\right]\leq\rho^{t}\Psi^{0}, (5)

where

ρ≔max⁡((1−γ​μ)2,(γ​L−1)2,1−p2​η​s−1n−1)<1.≔𝜌superscript1𝛾𝜇2superscript𝛾𝐿121superscript𝑝2𝜂𝑠1𝑛11\rho\coloneqq\max\left((1-\gamma\mu)^{2},(\gamma L-1)^{2},1-p^{2}\eta\frac{s-1}{n-1}\right)<1. (6)

Also, for every i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], (xit)t∈ℕsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡𝑡ℕ(x_{i}^{t})_{t\in\mathbb{N}} and (x^it)t∈ℕsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑖𝑡𝑡ℕ(\hat{x}_{i}^{t})_{t\in\mathbb{N}} both converge to x⋆superscript𝑥⋆x^{\star} and (hit)t∈ℕsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑡𝑡ℕ(h_{i}^{t})_{t\in\mathbb{N}} converges to hi⋆superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖⋆h_{i}^{\star}, almost surely.

Remark 3.2.

One can simply set η=12𝜂12\eta=\frac{1}{2} in CompressedScaffnew, which is independent of n𝑛n and s𝑠s. However, the larger η𝜂\eta, the better, so it is recommended to set

η=n​(s−1)s​(n−1).𝜂𝑛𝑠1𝑠𝑛1\eta=\frac{n(s-1)}{s(n-1)}. (7)

3.1 Iteration complexity

CompressedScaffnew has the same iteration complexity as GD, with rate ρ♯≔max(1−γμ,γL−1)2\rho^{\sharp}\coloneqq\max(1-\gamma\mu,\gamma L-1)^{2}, as long as p𝑝p and s𝑠s are large enough to have

1−p2​η​s−1n−1≤ρ♯.1superscript𝑝2𝜂𝑠1𝑛1superscript𝜌♯1-p^{2}\eta\frac{s-1}{n-1}\leq\rho^{\sharp}.

This is remarkable: compression during aggregation with p<1𝑝1p<1 and s<n𝑠𝑛s<n does not harm convergence at all, until some threshold. This is in contrast with other algorithms with CC, like DIANA, where even a small amount of compression worsens the worst-case complexity.

For any s≥2𝑠2s\geq 2, p∈(0,1]𝑝01p\in(0,1], γ=Θ​(1L)𝛾Θ1𝐿\gamma=\Theta(\frac{1}{L}), and fixed η∈(0,1]𝜂01\eta\in(0,1], the asymptotic iteration complexity of CompressedScaffnew to reach ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-accuracy, i.e. 𝔼​[Ψt]≤ϵ𝔼delimited-[]superscriptΨ𝑡italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}\!\left[\Psi^{t}\right]\leq\epsilon, is

𝒪​((κ+ns​p2)​log⁡(ϵ−1)).𝒪𝜅𝑛𝑠superscript𝑝2superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mathcal{O}\left(\left(\kappa+\frac{n}{sp^{2}}\right)\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\right). (8)

Thus, by choosing

p=min⁡((1−ρ♯)​(n−1)η​(s−1),1),𝑝1superscript𝜌♯𝑛1𝜂𝑠11p=\min\left(\sqrt{\frac{(1-\rho^{\sharp})(n-1)}{\eta(s-1)}},1\right), (9)

or more generally

p=min⁡(Θ​(ns​κ),1),𝑝Θ𝑛𝑠𝜅1p=\min\left(\Theta\left(\sqrt{\frac{n}{s\kappa}}\right),1\right), (10)

the iteration complexity becomes

𝒪​((κ+ns)​log⁡(ϵ−1)).𝒪𝜅𝑛𝑠superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mathcal{O}\left(\left(\kappa+\frac{n}{s}\right)\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\right).

In particular, with the choice recommended in (14) of s=max⁡(2,⌊nd⌋,⌊c​n⌋)𝑠2𝑛𝑑𝑐𝑛s=\max(2,\lfloor\frac{n}{d}\rfloor,\lfloor cn\rfloor), which yields the best TotalCom complexity, the iteration complexity is

𝒪​((κ+min⁡(d,n,1c))​log⁡(ϵ−1))𝒪𝜅𝑑𝑛1𝑐superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mathcal{O}\Big{(}\Big{(}\kappa+\min\!\big{(}d,n,{\textstyle\frac{1}{c}}\big{)}\Big{)}\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\Big{)}

(with 1c=+∞1𝑐\frac{1}{c}=+\infty if c=0𝑐0c=0).

3.2 Convergence in the convex case

In this section only, we remove the hypothesis of strong convexity: the functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} are just assumed to be convex and L𝐿L-smooth, and we suppose that a solution x⋆∈ℝdsuperscript𝑥⋆superscriptℝ𝑑x^{\star}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} to (1) exists. Then we have sublinear ergodic convergence:

Theorem 3.3.

In CompressedScaffnew, suppose that

0<γ<2Land0<η<n​(s−1)s​(n−1)∈(12,1].formulae-sequence0𝛾2𝐿and0𝜂𝑛𝑠1𝑠𝑛11210<\gamma<\frac{2}{L}\quad\mbox{and}\quad 0<\eta<\frac{n(s-1)}{s(n-1)}\in\left(\frac{1}{2},1\right]. (11)

For every i=1,…,n𝑖1…𝑛i=1,\ldots,n and T≥0𝑇0T\geq 0, we define

x~iT≔1T+1​∑t=0Txit.≔superscriptsubscript~𝑥𝑖𝑇1𝑇1superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡\tilde{x}_{i}^{T}\coloneqq\frac{1}{T+1}\sum_{t=0}^{T}x_{i}^{t}. (12)

Then

𝔼​[‖∇f​(x~iT)‖2]=𝒪​(1T)𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝑓superscriptsubscript~𝑥𝑖𝑇2𝒪1𝑇\mathbb{E}\!\left[\left\|\nabla f(\tilde{x}_{i}^{T})\right\|^{2}\right]=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{T}\right) (13)

(an explicit upper bound is given in the proof).

4 Communication complexity

For any s≥2𝑠2s\geq 2, p∈(0,1]𝑝01p\in(0,1], γ=Θ​(1L)𝛾Θ1𝐿\gamma=\Theta(\frac{1}{L}), and fixed η∈(0,1]𝜂01\eta\in(0,1], the asymptotic iteration complexity of CompressedScaffnew is given in (8). Communication occurs at every iteration with probability p𝑝p, and during every communication round, DownCom consists in broadcasting the full d𝑑d-dimensional vector x¯tsuperscript¯𝑥𝑡\bar{x}^{t}, whereas in UpCom, compression is effective and the number of real values sent in parallel by the clients is equal to the number of ones per column in the sampling pattern q𝑞q, which is ⌈s​dn⌉≥1𝑠𝑑𝑛1\lceil\frac{sd}{n}\rceil\geq 1. Hence, the communication complexities are:

DownCom:𝒪​(p​d​(κ+ns​p2)​log⁡(ϵ−1)),DownCom:𝒪𝑝𝑑𝜅𝑛𝑠superscript𝑝2superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mbox{DownCom:}\quad\mathcal{O}\left(pd\left(\kappa+\frac{n}{sp^{2}}\right)\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\right)\!,
UpCom:𝒪​(p​(s​dn+1)​(κ+ns​p2)​log⁡(ϵ−1)).UpCom:𝒪𝑝𝑠𝑑𝑛1𝜅𝑛𝑠superscript𝑝2superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mbox{UpCom:}\quad\mathcal{O}\left(p\left(\frac{sd}{n}+1\right)\left(\kappa+\frac{n}{sp^{2}}\right)\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\right)\!.
TotalCom:𝒪​(p​(s​dn+1+c​d)​(κ+ns​p2)​log⁡(ϵ−1)).TotalCom:𝒪𝑝𝑠𝑑𝑛1𝑐𝑑𝜅𝑛𝑠superscript𝑝2superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mbox{TotalCom:}\ \ \mathcal{O}\left(p\left(\frac{sd}{n}+1+cd\right)\left(\kappa+\frac{n}{sp^{2}}\right)\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\right)\!.

For a given s𝑠s, the best choice for p𝑝p, for both DownCom and UpCom, is given in (9), or more generally (10), for which

𝒪​(p​(κ+ns​p2))=𝒪​(n​κs+ns)𝒪𝑝𝜅𝑛𝑠superscript𝑝2𝒪𝑛𝜅𝑠𝑛𝑠\mathcal{O}\left(p\left(\kappa+\frac{n}{sp^{2}}\right)\right)=\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{\frac{n\kappa}{s}}+\frac{n}{s}\right)

and the TotalCom complexity is

TotalCom:𝒪​((n​κs+ns)​(s​dn+1+c​d)​log⁡(ϵ−1)).TotalCom:𝒪𝑛𝜅𝑠𝑛𝑠𝑠𝑑𝑛1𝑐𝑑superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mbox{TotalCom:}\ \ \mathcal{O}\left(\!\left(\sqrt{\frac{n\kappa}{s}}+\frac{n}{s}\right)\!\left(\frac{sd}{n}+1+cd\right)\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\!\right)\!.

We see the first acceleration effect due to LT: with a suitable p<1𝑝1p<1, the communication complexity only depends on κ𝜅\sqrt{\kappa}, not κ𝜅\kappa, whatever the compression level s𝑠s. Without compression, i.e. s=n𝑠𝑛s=n, CompressedScaffnew reverts to Scaffnew, with TotalCom complexity 𝒪​(d​κ​log⁡(ϵ−1))𝒪𝑑𝜅superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mathcal{O}\big{(}d\sqrt{\kappa}\log(\epsilon^{-1})\big{)}. We can now set s𝑠s to further accelerate the algorithm, by minimizing the TotalCom complexity:

Theorem 4.1.

In CompressedScaffnew, suppose that (3) holds, with η𝜂\eta fixed and γ=Θ​(1L)𝛾Θ1𝐿\gamma=\Theta(\frac{1}{L}), that p𝑝p satisfies (10) and that

s=max⁡(2,⌊nd⌋,⌊c​n⌋).𝑠2𝑛𝑑𝑐𝑛s=\max\left(2,\left\lfloor\frac{n}{d}\right\rfloor,\lfloor cn\rfloor\right). (14)

Then the TotalCom complexity of CompressedScaffnew is

𝒪​((d​κn+d​κ+d+c​d​κ)​log⁡(ϵ−1)).𝒪𝑑𝜅𝑛𝑑𝜅𝑑𝑐𝑑𝜅superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mathcal{O}\!\left(\left(d\frac{\sqrt{\kappa}}{\sqrt{n}}+\sqrt{d}\sqrt{\kappa}+d+\sqrt{c}\,d\sqrt{\kappa}\right)\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\right)\!. (15)

Hence, as long as c≤max⁡(2n,1d,1κ)𝑐2𝑛1𝑑1𝜅c\leq\max(\frac{2}{n},\frac{1}{d},\frac{1}{\kappa}), there is no difference with the case c=0𝑐0c=0, in which we only focus on UpCom, and the TotalCom complexity is

𝒪​((d​κn+d​κ+d)​log⁡(ϵ−1)).𝒪𝑑𝜅𝑛𝑑𝜅𝑑superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mathcal{O}\!\left(\left(d\frac{\sqrt{\kappa}}{\sqrt{n}}+\sqrt{d}\sqrt{\kappa}+d\right)\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\right)\!.

On the other hand, if c≥max⁡(2n,1d,1κ)𝑐2𝑛1𝑑1𝜅c\geq\max(\frac{2}{n},\frac{1}{d},\frac{1}{\kappa}), the complexity increases and becomes

𝒪​(c​d​κ​log⁡(ϵ−1)),𝒪𝑐𝑑𝜅superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mathcal{O}\Big{(}\sqrt{c}\,d\sqrt{\kappa}\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\Big{)},

but compression remains operational and effective with the c𝑐\sqrt{c} factor. It is only when c=1𝑐1c=1 that s=n𝑠𝑛s=n, i.e. there is no compression and CompressedScaffnew reverts to Scaffnew, and that the Upcom, DownCom and TotalCom complexities all become

𝒪​(d​κ​log⁡(ϵ−1)).𝒪𝑑𝜅superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mathcal{O}\Big{(}d\sqrt{\kappa}\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\Big{)}.

In any case, for every c∈[0,1]𝑐01c\in[0,1], CompressedScaffnew is faster than Scaffnew.

We have reported in Table 1 the TotalCom complexity for several algorithms, and to the best of our knowledge, CompressedScaffnew improves upon all known algorithms, which use either LT or CC on top of GD.

5 Experiments

Carrying out large-scale experiments is beyond the scope of this work, which limits itself to foundational algorithmic and theoretical properties of above-mentioned algorithms. Nevertheless, we illustrate and confirm our results on a practical logistic regression problem.

The global loss function is

f​(x)=1M​∑m=1Mlog⁡(1+exp⁡(−bm​am⊤​x))+μ2​‖x‖2,𝑓𝑥1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀1subscript𝑏𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑚top𝑥𝜇2superscriptnorm𝑥2f(x)=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\log(1+\exp(-b_{m}a_{m}^{\top}x))+\frac{\mu}{2}\|x\|^{2}, (16)

where the am∈ℝdsubscript𝑎𝑚superscriptℝ𝑑a_{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and bm∈{−1,1}subscript𝑏𝑚11b_{m}\in\{-1,1\} are data samples and M𝑀M is their total number. The function f𝑓f in (16) is split into n𝑛n functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} (the remainder of M𝑀M divided by n𝑛n samples is discarded). The strong convexity parameter μ𝜇\mu is set to 0.003​L00.003subscript𝐿00.003L_{0} in Figure 2 and 10−6​L0superscript106subscript𝐿010^{-6}L_{0} in Figure 3, where L0subscript𝐿0L_{0} is the smoothness constant without the μ2​‖x‖2𝜇2superscriptnorm𝑥2\frac{\mu}{2}\|x\|^{2} term (so that L=L0+μ)L=L_{0}+\mu). We consider the case where the number of clients is larger than the model dimension (n>d𝑛𝑑n>d) and vice versa. For this, we use the ‘w8a’ and ‘real-sim’ datasets from the classical LIBSVM library (Chang and Lin,, 2011). For each of them, we consider the two cases c=0𝑐0c=0 and c=0.2𝑐0.2c=0.2.

We measure the convergence error f​(x)−f​(x⋆)𝑓𝑥𝑓superscript𝑥⋆f(x)-f(x^{\star}) with respect to the TotalCom amount of communication, where x𝑥x is xtsuperscript𝑥𝑡x^{t} for GD and x¯tsuperscript¯𝑥𝑡\bar{x}^{t} when communication occurs for CompressedScaffnew and Scaffnew. The objective gap f​(x)−f​(x⋆)𝑓𝑥𝑓superscript𝑥⋆f(x)-f(x^{\star}) is a fair way to compare different algorithms and, since f𝑓f is L𝐿L-smooth, f​(x)−f​(x⋆)≤L2​‖x−x⋆‖2𝑓𝑥𝑓superscript𝑥⋆𝐿2superscriptnorm𝑥superscript𝑥⋆2f(x)-f(x^{\star})\leq\frac{L}{2}\|x-x^{\star}\|^{2} for any x𝑥x, so that it is guaranteed to converge linearly with the same rate as ΨΨ\Psi in Theorem 3.1.

The stepsize γ=2L+μ𝛾2𝐿𝜇\gamma=\frac{2}{L+\mu} is used in all algorithms. The probability p𝑝p is set to 1κ1𝜅\frac{1}{\sqrt{\kappa}} for Scaffnew and min⁡(ns​κ,1)𝑛𝑠𝜅1\min(\sqrt{\frac{n}{s\kappa}},1) for CompressedScaffnew, with s𝑠s and η𝜂\eta set according to Equations (14) and (7), respectively. x0superscript𝑥0x^{0} and the hi0superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖0h_{i}^{0} are all set to zero vectors.

The results are shown in Figures 2 and 3. The algorithms converge linearly, and CompressedScaffnew is faster than Scaffnew, as expected. This confirms that the proposed compression technique is effective. The speedup of CompressedScaffnew over Scaffnew is higher for c=0𝑐0c=0 than for c=0.2𝑐0.2c=0.2. This is also expected, since when c𝑐c increases, there is less compression and the two algorithms become more similar; they are the same, without compression, when c=1𝑐1c=1.

6 Conclusion

Our proposed algorithm CompressedScaffnew is the first to provably benefit from the two combined acceleration mechanisms of Local Training (LT) and Communication Compression (CC). Moreover, this is achieved not only for uplink communication, but for our more comprehensive model of total communication. Our theoretical achievements are confirmed in practice. This pushes the boundary of our understanding of LT and CC to a new level. Among venues for future work, we can mention replacing the true gradients ∇fi∇subscript𝑓𝑖\nabla f_{i} by stochastic estimates, a feature present in several algorithms like Scaffnew (Malinovsky et al.,, 2022) and FedCOMGATE (Haddadpour et al.,, 2021), or allowing for partial participation and for a larger class of possibly biased compressors, including quantization. The nonconvex case should also be studied (Karimireddy et al.,, 2021; Das et al.,, 2022).

Appendix A Proof of Theorem 3.1

We introduce vector notations to simplify the derivations: the problem (1) can be written as

Algorithm 2 converges linearly:

Theorem A.1.

In Algorithm 2, suppose that 0<γ<2L0𝛾2𝐿0<\gamma<\frac{2}{L} and that τ≤pγ​n​(s−1)s​(n−1)𝜏𝑝𝛾𝑛𝑠1𝑠𝑛1\tau\leq\frac{p}{\gamma}\frac{n(s-1)}{s(n-1)}. For every t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0, define the Lyapunov function

Ψt≔1γ​‖𝐱t−𝐱⋆‖2+1+ωτ​‖𝐮t−𝐮⋆‖2,≔superscriptΨ𝑡1𝛾superscriptnormsuperscript𝐱𝑡superscript𝐱⋆21𝜔𝜏superscriptnormsuperscript𝐮𝑡superscript𝐮⋆2\Psi^{t}\coloneqq\frac{1}{\gamma}\left\|\mathbf{x}^{t}-\mathbf{x}^{\star}\right\|^{2}+\frac{1+\omega}{\tau}\left\|\mathbf{u}^{t}-\mathbf{u}^{\star}\right\|^{2}, (19)

𝔼​[Ψt]≤ρt​Ψ0,𝔼delimited-[]superscriptΨ𝑡superscript𝜌𝑡superscriptΨ0\mathbb{E}\!\left[\Psi^{t}\right]\leq\rho^{t}\Psi^{0}, (20)

Also, (𝐱t)t∈ℕsubscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑡𝑡ℕ(\mathbf{x}^{t})_{t\in\mathbb{N}} and (𝐱^t)t∈ℕsubscriptsuperscript^𝐱𝑡𝑡ℕ(\mathbf{\hat{x}}^{t})_{t\in\mathbb{N}} both converge to 𝐱⋆superscript𝐱⋆\mathbf{x}^{\star} and (𝐮t)t∈ℕsubscriptsuperscript𝐮𝑡𝑡ℕ(\mathbf{u}^{t})_{t\in\mathbb{N}} converges to 𝐮⋆superscript𝐮⋆\mathbf{u}^{\star}, almost surely.

Proof.

For every t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0, we define 𝐮^t+1≔𝐮t+τ​W​𝐱^t≔superscript^𝐮𝑡1superscript𝐮𝑡𝜏𝑊superscript^𝐱𝑡\mathbf{\hat{u}}^{t+1}\coloneqq\mathbf{u}^{t}+\tau W\mathbf{\hat{x}}^{t}, 𝐰t≔𝐱t−γ​∇𝐟​(𝐱t)≔superscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐱𝑡𝛾∇𝐟superscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{w}^{t}\coloneqq\mathbf{x}^{t}-\gamma\nabla\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}^{t}) and 𝐰⋆≔𝐱⋆−γ​∇𝐟​(𝐱⋆)≔superscript𝐰⋆superscript𝐱⋆𝛾∇𝐟superscript𝐱⋆\mathbf{w}^{\star}\coloneqq\mathbf{x}^{\star}-\gamma\nabla\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}^{\star}). We also define 𝐱¯t​♯≔(x¯t​♯)i=1n≔superscript¯𝐱𝑡♯superscriptsubscriptsuperscript¯𝑥𝑡♯𝑖1𝑛\mathbf{\bar{x}}^{t\sharp}\coloneqq(\bar{x}^{t\sharp})_{i=1}^{n}, with x¯t​♯≔1n​∑i=1nx^it≔superscript¯𝑥𝑡♯1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑖𝑡\bar{x}^{t\sharp}\coloneqq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\hat{x}_{i}^{t}; that is, x¯t​♯superscript¯𝑥𝑡♯\bar{x}^{t\sharp} is the exact average of the x^itsuperscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑖𝑡\hat{x}_{i}^{t}, of which x¯tsuperscript¯𝑥𝑡\bar{x}^{t} is an unbiased random estimate.

We have

𝔼​[‖𝐱t+1−𝐱⋆‖2|ℱt]𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptnormsuperscript𝐱𝑡1superscript𝐱⋆2subscriptℱ𝑡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\!\left[\left\|\mathbf{x}^{t+1}-\mathbf{x}^{\star}\right\|^{2}\;|\;\mathcal{F}_{t}\right] =p​𝔼𝐪t​[‖𝐱¯t−𝐱⋆‖2|ℱt]+(1−p)​‖𝐱^t−𝐱⋆‖2,absent𝑝subscript𝔼superscript𝐪𝑡delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptnormsuperscript¯𝐱𝑡superscript𝐱⋆2subscriptℱ𝑡1𝑝superscriptnormsuperscript^𝐱𝑡superscript𝐱⋆2\displaystyle=p\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{q}^{t}}\!\left[\left\|\mathbf{\bar{x}}^{t}-\mathbf{x}^{\star}\right\|^{2}\;|\;\mathcal{F}_{t}\right]+(1-p)\left\|\mathbf{\hat{x}}^{t}-\mathbf{x}^{\star}\right\|^{2},

where 𝔼𝐪tsubscript𝔼superscript𝐪𝑡\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{q}^{t}} denotes the expectation with respect to the random mask 𝐪tsuperscript𝐪𝑡\mathbf{q}^{t}. To analyze 𝔼𝐪t​[‖𝐱¯t−𝐱⋆‖2|ℱt]subscript𝔼superscript𝐪𝑡delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptnormsuperscript¯𝐱𝑡superscript𝐱⋆2subscriptℱ𝑡\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{q}^{t}}\!\left[\left\|\mathbf{\bar{x}}^{t}-\mathbf{x}^{\star}\right\|^{2}\;|\;\mathcal{F}_{t}\right], we can remark that the expectation and the squared Euclidean norm are separable with respect to the coordinates of the d𝑑d-dimensional vectors, so that we can reason on the coordinates independently on each other, even if the the coordinates, or rows, of 𝐪tsuperscript𝐪𝑡\mathbf{q}^{t} are mutually dependent. x¯kt=1s​∑i∈Ωktx^i,kt.subscriptsuperscript¯𝑥𝑡𝑘1𝑠subscript𝑖superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑖𝑘𝑡\bar{x}^{t}_{k}=\frac{1}{s}\sum_{i\in\Omega_{k}^{t}}\hat{x}_{i,k}^{t}.

𝔼𝐪t​[‖𝐱¯t−𝐱¯t​♯‖2|ℱt]=n​∑k=1d𝔼Ωkt​[(1s​∑i∈Ωktx^i,kt−1n​∑j=1nx^j,kt)2|ℱt]=ν​‖W​𝐱^t‖2,subscript𝔼superscript𝐪𝑡delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptnormsuperscript¯𝐱𝑡superscript¯𝐱𝑡♯2subscriptℱ𝑡𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑑subscript𝔼superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑘𝑡delimited-[]conditionalsuperscript1𝑠subscript𝑖superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑖𝑘𝑡1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛superscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑗𝑘𝑡2subscriptℱ𝑡𝜈superscriptnorm𝑊superscript^𝐱𝑡2\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{q}^{t}}\!\left[\left\|\mathbf{\bar{x}}^{t}-\mathbf{\bar{x}}^{t\sharp}\right\|^{2}\;|\;\mathcal{F}_{t}\right]=n\sum_{k=1}^{d}\mathbb{E}_{\Omega_{k}^{t}}\!\left[\left(\frac{1}{s}\sum_{i\in\Omega_{k}^{t}}\hat{x}_{i,k}^{t}-\frac{1}{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}\hat{x}_{j,k}^{t}\right)^{2}\;|\;\mathcal{F}_{t}\right]=\nu\left\|W\mathbf{\hat{x}}^{t}\right\|^{2},

Since we have supposed τ−pγ​(1−ν)≤0𝜏𝑝𝛾1𝜈0\tau-\frac{p}{\gamma}(1-\nu)\leq 0,

1γ​𝔼​[‖𝐱t+1−𝐱⋆‖2|ℱt]+1+ωτ​𝔼​[‖𝐮t+1−𝐮⋆‖2|ℱt]1𝛾𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptnormsuperscript𝐱𝑡1superscript𝐱⋆2subscriptℱ𝑡1𝜔𝜏𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptnormsuperscript𝐮𝑡1superscript𝐮⋆2subscriptℱ𝑡\displaystyle\frac{1}{\gamma}\mathbb{E}\!\left[\left\|\mathbf{x}^{t+1}-\mathbf{x}^{\star}\right\|^{2}\;|\;\mathcal{F}_{t}\right]+\frac{1+\omega}{\tau}\mathbb{E}\!\left[\left\|\mathbf{u}^{t+1}-\mathbf{u}^{\star}\right\|^{2}\;|\;\mathcal{F}_{t}\right]
≤1γ​‖𝐰t−𝐰⋆‖2+1+ωτ​(1−γ​τ1+ω)​‖𝐮t−𝐮⋆‖2.absent1𝛾superscriptnormsuperscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰⋆21𝜔𝜏1𝛾𝜏1𝜔superscriptnormsuperscript𝐮𝑡superscript𝐮⋆2\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\leq\frac{1}{\gamma}\left\|\mathbf{w}^{t}-\mathbf{w}^{\star}\right\|^{2}+\frac{1+\omega}{\tau}\left(1-\frac{\gamma\tau}{1+\omega}\right)\left\|\mathbf{u}^{t}-\mathbf{u}^{\star}\right\|^{2}.

According to Condat and Richtárik, (2022, Lemma 1),

‖𝐰t−𝐰⋆‖2superscriptnormsuperscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰⋆2\displaystyle\left\|\mathbf{w}^{t}-\mathbf{w}^{\star}\right\|^{2} =‖(Id−γ​∇𝐟)​𝐱t−(Id−γ​∇𝐟)​𝐱⋆‖2absentsuperscriptnormId𝛾∇𝐟superscript𝐱𝑡Id𝛾∇𝐟superscript𝐱⋆2\displaystyle=\left\|(\mathrm{Id}-\gamma\nabla\mathbf{f})\mathbf{x}^{t}-(\mathrm{Id}-\gamma\nabla\mathbf{f})\mathbf{x}^{\star}\right\|^{2}
≤max(1−γμ,γL−1)2∥𝐱t−𝐱⋆∥2.\displaystyle\leq\max(1-\gamma\mu,\gamma L-1)^{2}\left\|\mathbf{x}^{t}-\mathbf{x}^{\star}\right\|^{2}.

Therefore,

𝔼​[Ψt+1|ℱt]𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptΨ𝑡1subscriptℱ𝑡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\!\left[\Psi^{t+1}\;|\;\mathcal{F}_{t}\right] ≤max⁡((1−γ​μ)2,(γ​L−1)2,1−γ​τ1+ω)​Ψt.absentsuperscript1𝛾𝜇2superscript𝛾𝐿121𝛾𝜏1𝜔superscriptΨ𝑡\displaystyle\leq\max\left((1-\gamma\mu)^{2},(\gamma L-1)^{2},1-\frac{\gamma\tau}{1+\omega}\right)\Psi^{t}. (24)

Using the tower rule, we can unroll the recursion in (24) to obtain the unconditional expectation of Ψt+1superscriptΨ𝑡1\Psi^{t+1}. Moreover, using classical results on supermartingale convergence (Bertsekas,, 2015, Proposition A.4.5), it follows from (24) that Ψt→0→superscriptΨ𝑡0\Psi^{t}\rightarrow 0 almost surely. Almost sure convergence of 𝐱tsuperscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{x}^{t} and 𝐮tsuperscript𝐮𝑡\mathbf{u}^{t} follows. Finally, by Lipschitz continuity of ∇𝐟∇𝐟\nabla\mathbf{f}, we can upper bound ‖𝐱^t−𝐱⋆‖2superscriptnormsuperscript^𝐱𝑡superscript𝐱⋆2\|\mathbf{\hat{x}}^{t}-\mathbf{x}^{\star}\|^{2} by a linear combination of ‖𝐱t−𝐱⋆‖2superscriptnormsuperscript𝐱𝑡superscript𝐱⋆2\|\mathbf{x}^{t}-\mathbf{x}^{\star}\|^{2} and ‖𝐮t−𝐮⋆‖2superscriptnormsuperscript𝐮𝑡superscript𝐮⋆2\|\mathbf{u}^{t}-\mathbf{u}^{\star}\|^{2}. It follows that 𝔼​[‖𝐱^t−𝐱⋆‖2]→0→𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript^𝐱𝑡superscript𝐱⋆20\mathbb{E}\!\left[\left\|\mathbf{\hat{x}}^{t}-\mathbf{x}^{\star}\right\|^{2}\right]\rightarrow 0 linearly with the same rate ρ𝜌\rho and that 𝐱^t→𝐱⋆→superscript^𝐱𝑡superscript𝐱⋆\mathbf{\hat{x}}^{t}\rightarrow\mathbf{x}^{\star} almost surely, as well. ∎


CompressedScaffnew corresponds to Algorithm 2 with uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} replaced by −hisubscriptℎ𝑖-h_{i}, the randomization strategy for the dual update detailed in Section A.1, the variance factors ω𝜔\omega and ν𝜈\nu defined in (27) and (22), respectively, and τ≔pγ​η≔𝜏𝑝𝛾𝜂\tau\coloneqq\frac{p}{\gamma}\eta, for some η𝜂\eta with

0<η≤1−ν=n​(s−1)s​(n−1)∈(12,1].0𝜂1𝜈𝑛𝑠1𝑠𝑛11210<\eta\leq 1-\nu=\frac{n(s-1)}{s(n-1)}\in\left(\frac{1}{2},1\right].

With these substitutions, Theorem A.1 yields Theorem 3.1.

Appendix B Proof of Theorem 4.1

We suppose that the assumptions in Theorem 4.1 hold. s𝑠s is set as the maximum of three values. Let us consider these three cases.

1) Suppose that s=2𝑠2s=2. Since 2=s≥⌊c​n⌋2𝑠𝑐𝑛2=s\geq\lfloor cn\rfloor and 2=s≥⌊nd⌋2𝑠𝑛𝑑2=s\geq\lfloor\frac{n}{d}\rfloor, we have c≤3n𝑐3𝑛c\leq\frac{3}{n} and 1≤3​dn13𝑑𝑛1\leq\frac{3d}{n}. Hence,

𝒪​(n​κs+ns)​(s​dn+1+c​d)𝒪𝑛𝜅𝑠𝑛𝑠𝑠𝑑𝑛1𝑐𝑑\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{\frac{n\kappa}{s}}+\frac{n}{s}\right)\!\left(\frac{sd}{n}+1+cd\right)
=\displaystyle={} 𝒪​(n​κ+n)​(dn+dn+dn)𝒪𝑛𝜅𝑛𝑑𝑛𝑑𝑛𝑑𝑛\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{n\kappa}+n\right)\!\left(\frac{d}{n}+\frac{d}{n}+\frac{d}{n}\right)
=\displaystyle={} 𝒪​(d​κn+d).𝒪𝑑𝜅𝑛𝑑\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{d\sqrt{\kappa}}{\sqrt{n}}+d\right). (28)

2) Suppose that s=⌊nd⌋𝑠𝑛𝑑s=\lfloor\frac{n}{d}\rfloor. Then s​dn≤1𝑠𝑑𝑛1\frac{sd}{n}\leq 1. Since s≥⌊c​n⌋𝑠𝑐𝑛s\geq\lfloor cn\rfloor and ⌊nd⌋=s≥2𝑛𝑑𝑠2\lfloor\frac{n}{d}\rfloor=s\geq 2, we have c​n≤s+1≤nd+1𝑐𝑛𝑠1𝑛𝑑1cn\leq s+1\leq\frac{n}{d}+1 and dn≤12𝑑𝑛12\frac{d}{n}\leq\frac{1}{2}, so that c​d≤1+dn≤2𝑐𝑑1𝑑𝑛2cd\leq 1+\frac{d}{n}\leq 2. Hence,

𝒪​(n​κs+ns)​(s​dn+1+c​d)𝒪𝑛𝜅𝑠𝑛𝑠𝑠𝑑𝑛1𝑐𝑑\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{\frac{n\kappa}{s}}+\frac{n}{s}\right)\!\left(\frac{sd}{n}+1+cd\right)
=\displaystyle={} 𝒪​(n​κs+ns).𝒪𝑛𝜅𝑠𝑛𝑠\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{\frac{n\kappa}{s}}+\frac{n}{s}\right).

Since 2​s≥nd2𝑠𝑛𝑑2s\geq\frac{n}{d}, we have 1s≤2​dn1𝑠2𝑑𝑛\frac{1}{s}\leq\frac{2d}{n} and

𝒪​(n​κs+ns)​(s​dn+1+c​d)𝒪𝑛𝜅𝑠𝑛𝑠𝑠𝑑𝑛1𝑐𝑑\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{\frac{n\kappa}{s}}+\frac{n}{s}\right)\!\left(\frac{sd}{n}+1+cd\right)
=\displaystyle={} 𝒪​(d​κ+d).𝒪𝑑𝜅𝑑\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{d\kappa}+d\right). (29)

3) Suppose that s=⌊c​n⌋𝑠𝑐𝑛s=\lfloor cn\rfloor. Then s≤c​n𝑠𝑐𝑛s\leq cn. Also, 2​s≥c​n2𝑠𝑐𝑛2s\geq cn and 1s≤2c​n1𝑠2𝑐𝑛\frac{1}{s}\leq\frac{2}{cn}. Since s=⌊c​n⌋≥⌊nd⌋𝑠𝑐𝑛𝑛𝑑s=\lfloor cn\rfloor\geq\lfloor\frac{n}{d}\rfloor, we have c​n+1≥nd𝑐𝑛1𝑛𝑑cn+1\geq\frac{n}{d} and 1≤c​d+dn1𝑐𝑑𝑑𝑛1\leq cd+\frac{d}{n}. Since s=⌊c​n⌋≥2𝑠𝑐𝑛2s=\lfloor cn\rfloor\geq 2, we have 1n≤c21𝑛𝑐2\frac{1}{n}\leq\frac{c}{2} and 1≤2​c​d12𝑐𝑑1\leq 2cd. Hence,

𝒪​(n​κs+ns)​(s​dn+1+c​d)𝒪𝑛𝜅𝑠𝑛𝑠𝑠𝑑𝑛1𝑐𝑑\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{\frac{n\kappa}{s}}+\frac{n}{s}\right)\!\left(\frac{sd}{n}+1+cd\right)
=\displaystyle={} 𝒪​(κc+1c)​(c​d+c​d+c​d)𝒪𝜅𝑐1𝑐𝑐𝑑𝑐𝑑𝑐𝑑\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{\frac{\kappa}{c}}+\frac{1}{c}\right)\!\left(cd+cd+cd\right)
=\displaystyle={} 𝒪​(c​κ​d+d).𝒪𝑐𝜅𝑑𝑑\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{c\kappa}d+d\right). (30)

By adding up the three upper bounds (28), (29), (30), we obtain the upper bound in (15).
